headline: Eggs Benedict Casserole
description: This eggs Benedict casserole delivers all the flavors of the popular breakfast dish with an easy overnight recipe that's great for when guests come.

video.description: Baked breakfast casserole with English muffins and Canadian bacon.
video.name: Eggs Benedict Casserole

name: Eggs Benedict Casserole
recipeIngredient: 0.75 pound Canadian bacon, cut into 1/2-inch dice

recipeInstructions.text: Grease a 9x13-inch baking dish with cooking spray.
Prepare casserole: Whisk together milk, eggs, green onions, onion powder, and salt in a large bowl until well combined. Set aside.

Layer 1/2 of the Canadian bacon in the prepared baking dish. Cover with English muffins. Top with remaining Canadian bacon, then pour egg mixture over everything. Cover the baking dish with plastic wrap and refrigerate, 8 hours to overnight.
Preheat the oven to 375 degrees F (190 degrees C).
Remove plastic wrap from the baking dish. Sprinkle casserole with paprika and cover the baking dish with aluminum foil.
Bake in the preheated oven until eggs are nearly set, about 30 minutes. Remove the foil and continue baking until eggs are completely set, about 15 minutes more.

When casserole is almost finished baking, make sauce: Whisk together remaining milk and Hollandaise sauce mix in a saucepan over medium heat. Add margarine; cook, stirring frequently, until boiling. Reduce heat to medium-low and simmer, stirring constantly, until thickened, about 1 minute.
Slice casserole into 10 pieces. Drizzle warm sauce over each piece.

review.reviewBody: Made my own Hollandaise sauce. Changed Canadian bacon to smoked salmon. Quick and so delicious!
I made this and my family LOVED it!! I did not make any changes. This will make it into my favorites!!
Made this for Christmas morning. Big hit! Will use two packets of sauce next time.
I've made this Christmas breakfast for three years now. Everyone loves it, even the picky eaters. It has become a family tradition.
I agree with making 2 pkgs of Hollandaise sauce! YUM. I also like to add a little chopped kale, and extra green onion. It's requested for every Christmas morning.
Amazing!

I love eggs Benedict but only liked this. I think the eggs or English Muffins needed more flavor. Couldn’t say what but bites without the hollandaise were lacking some punch. Bake time was almost an hour in my oven. Would experiment and make again. Love this idea! Thank you!
I made this for my daughter’s 20th bday breakfast.my family loved it

My adjustments were to use diced ham rather than Canadian bacon and I added about 3 oz. sliced baby Swiss cut into small pieces on top. I also lightly toasted the muffins before cubing. My whole family enjoyed it, however I feel like needed some freshness to cut through the richness. Next time I may add some lemon zest into the egg mixture, a pinch of cayenne or some fresh parsley. It had a nice bread to egg mixture ratio. I baked it at 350 for 45 minutes since I needed that temp for other items. A big winner for our brunch today.
Perfect addition to our Easter breakfast table! I adapted this recipe to be more diabetic friendly by using whole wheat English muffins. Everyone loved it.

Like another reviewer, I toast the muffins for extra texture, dice them up and let them dry out for several hours. I also stir in about a teaspoon of Dijon mustard with the eggs. I have made this with diced parboiled asparagus layered in with the ham, it was tasty and looked pretty. Favorite variation is to sprinkle a cup of shredded Swiss cheese on top for the last 15 minutes of baking, and serve with avocado slices on the side. Now that's yummy.

I love Eggs Benedict! I changed up the recipe on a couple of things. I toasted the English muffins then placed in casserole dish, i used ham and sliced like canadian bacon and lightly fried on both sides then placed on English muffins. Egg mixture i used 1/4 c. Finely chopped Vidalia onion and added 4 cheese cheddar and whisked, poured over English muffins and ham and refrigerated overnight. Left out onion powder but added salt & pepper , sprinkled paprika before putting in oven. When done used 2 pkgs hollandaise sauce mix (i luv hollandaise sauce). Just absolutely delicious ??
So good!! This is a keeper for sure. I had to bake an additional 30 minutes, with the foil off, to get the eggs to set. But this recipe is a keeper!
My husband and I absolutely loved it!
hey guys hows it goin lol
I, in general, do not like any casseroles. This was so good and my guests loved it. I did top mine with quarters grape tomatoes for a touch of acid to break up some of the richness.
I made the casserole just as the recipe instructed and it was good. It would have been much better if I had made a homemade Hollandaise sauce instead of using the packet.

My husband and I did not like this at all. It didn't have much taste except for the hollandaise sauce which tasted awful. 
Never ever will make this again.
This is my favorite breakfast. And I absolutely luv egg casseroles. This is perfect combo. Make extra hollandaise!!
Definitely make your own sauce. Use real bacon instead of that ham in the video.

This felt like bread was the main ingredient and it really spoiled i for me. Will try this again in a cast iron frying pan, will add pre sauteed onions and mushrooms. Will end up with a kind of fritata. Much healthier and better tasting, even without the holondaise (which I love).

This is now a favorite. I made it in a hurry one morning not reading the overnight refrigeration part and you’d never know the difference! Used a dash of garlic powder instead of onion powder. Sprinkled a little diced Roma tomato on top for added color before serving. Delicious!
Made this for Christmas breakfast and it was a complete hit!! My family LOVED it! It will be a new Christmas morning tradition from here on out!

This is a great recipe. I had to adjust based on what I had on hand. I used a pound of bacon instead of ham and I used 3 toasted and cut up everything bagels ( they were big so that is why 3) instead of English muffins. I also didn’t have green onions so I just added onion powder. I also added garlic powder and paprika. I didn’t have time to let sit overnight so I just cooked right away. I think it was good this way a touch crunchy and then I used the knorr packet for eggs Benedict and it was fabulous! My picky kids loved it. I’m planning to make Christmas morning.
It has good flavour but a bit to heavy on the bread for my taste
I have made this several times. It is one of our favorites, with my kids requesting it every time they visit. I do make my own hollandaise sauce.
this is simply delish. made exactly to recipe. thanks!

Its a delicious filling breakfast, I made some slight changes. I cut the english muffins into quarters and then layered them on the bottom, diced some leftover ham, and put that on top before pouring the egg mixture over top. Finally, I found it just a little too oniony for me so I won't put in the onion powder next time.
Used leftover spiral cut ham- yumm!
Easier than a traditional "wife saver" and very flavorful. We served with a side of steamed asparagus and this was a big hit at our Christmas brunch. Will make this again soon!

This was amazing! By far the best and most moist Christmas casserole I’ve ever made. Will definitely make again. I added spinach leaves because I love them in casseroles with eggs. Also added garlic, cumin, and celery salt. Definitely recommend making your own hollandaise from this website. It really is better than the packages. A keeper. Thanks for the recipe!
A tasty and "easy to make" substitute for the real deal--the only thing missing is the runny yoke, which would have earned it 5 stars.

this is the second Christmas in a row I've made this. I do extra Hollandaise sauce on the side( 2 people who won't eat it) so you can add as much as you want. I am definitely doing this again.. maybe I will remember pictures the next time.
Fabulous - served it with a fresh poached egg on top!

I made it with thick bacon instead of Canadien bacon which I cooked in the oven first. We served your one minute Hollandaise recipe on the side and everyone loved it. I would definitely make it again!

My family loved it and asked that this become our new holiday breakfast casserole. Instead of Canadian bacon I used regular bacon, crumbled. Also, I added 2 eggs and a little more milk, and 2 cups of shredded mild cheddar on the top.
No changes made. Made it for friends for football brunch. Everyone loved it!! DELISH!!!
Made for my family on vacation, huge hit! Everyone wanted the recipe! Will definitely be making and sharing this dish!
Wonderful. Halved the recipe and added a little garlic salt. Made homemade hollandaise
Yummy and easy.
tried with cubed ham but think the canadian bacon is much better
Don't understand all the rave reviews. I followed the recipe exactly as written, and it came out quite flavorless (except for the Hollandaise sauce, LOL).
This was very easy to make and turned out great.
Followed the recipe and got rave reviews from the family.. Will definitely make this one again.
Great for any brunch. I did toast the English muffins on a baking sheet to give them a little more flavor
It was easy to make and so delicious!

Tried this for Christmas morning casserole as something different than in the past. It was a big hit. Easy to make and flavor was tasty. I made a homemade hollandaise sauce from this site as topping. I will definitely make again.
No changes. Will make again. Have shared recipe with my sister it was so good.

I made this for a Christmas potluck breakfast at work. Instead of using a baking dish, I put the ingredients in the crock pot 'insert' and then baked it in that the following morning (45 minutes covered and it was perfectly done). I brought the crock pot to work and kept in on warm until we started. Everyone raved about it and several asked for the recipe. Will make this for Christmas breakfast instead of traditional eggs benedict - so much easier and all the same great tastes!
UPDATE: I just made this for Easter breakfast tomorrow (going to bake it the traditional way) and recommend adding another 3-4 eggs with a bit more milk and onion powder.
use 2.5-3 cups cut up peameal and 4 cut up eng muffins.

Loved this recipe! Really hit the spot.
What wonderful make ahead recipe. Used french bread instead of English muffins. Will definitely try English muffins next time.
Also great with knor hollandiase mix.

I ALWAYS make a new to me recipe AS PRESENTED. This is a GREAT recipe. I made it as presented twice. After the trial run, I made the following changes:

Add garlic (fresh OR powdered) and WHITE PEPPER to the eggs and use a blender to scramble the eggs. Use UNCURED ham or bacon.

After the cooking process, sprinkle sharp white cheddar cheese, THEN add the green onion. (I like the crunch and freshness of the green onion).

Cover the Casserole EVENLY with the hollandaise sauce and serve. 

YUMMY.

THIS IS NOT A HEALTH FOOD, however, if one does not eat like this everyday, it makes a really nice treat to greet a weekend morning.

Try some green chile or a dash of cayenne pepper sauce and be keen not to overpower the dish with the spice of your choosing.

Try it my way. You will NOT be disappointed.

Too much bread and not enough egg for my husband and myself. I had to throw some away. Agree with the packaged hollandaise sauce comments too. From scratch is better. The packaged sauce had an odd smell that was hard to get passed. I wish this recipe would have turned out, I really liked the concept
Yummy! I always do lots of onions with everything but I was able to do this almost by the letter.

ok this was excellent I didn't change anything in the recipe but I did make it smaller...2 English muffins 4 slices of Canadian bacon 3 Eggs w/ 1/2 cup of milk 2 Green onions and eyeballed the onion powder and salt 

will definitely make again perfect for 1 person to have for dinner and lunch the next day
It was kinda bland, i followed recipe exact... need an little extra something in it to give it a bit more flavor
Just didn’t like it ever much
One of my new favorites! Easy and delicious.
Family loved it! A definite keeper.
A little bland but easy to make and a nice change from my regular ‘go to’ breakfast casseroles.

We have an empty nest.so I cut it back to 5 eggs.
My 15 yr old Scottish terrier LOVES EGGS! 
So that was his tear. The rest was my snack next morning@
.., awe..
Heaven!
The casserole was ok but unimpressive. The packaged Hollandaise sauce ruined it. the sauce only had a hint of lemon, but the worst part was it had sugar in it, totally ruining it for me.

I used 1/2 heavy cream and 1/2 whole milk. I added grated havarti or baby swiss cheese into egg mixture. Make sure you cooked Canada Bacons or use already cooked ham. I used Knorr hollandaise package. My family & friends love it.

Delicious! If you choose to make your own Hollandaise, remember that you’ll be adding a LOT more fat and calories. I’ve used packaged Hollandaise on eggs and veggies for several years and no one complains at all. Yes, slightly different flavor, but very good!
Not a fan. Will not make again.
I have made this numerous times and it is always a fun big hit. Easy, delicious and can be made ahead of time.
Easy recipe that is a crowd pleaser.
Excellent...very easy to make....everything done night before so time in am to mingle with house guests...used ham steak instead Of Canadian bacon.
This is always a big hit at brunch. I make it just as the recipe calls for, but I usually make my own hollandaise and let guests spoon it on themselves.

I love this casserole!! It is so easy and delicious. We love eggs Benedict and this recipe makes it easy to serve a large crowd. I follow the recipe exactly expect I toast my English muffins before cutting them up. I also just assemble the whole thing and put it in the oven right away. This way the bread isn’t as “mushy”. It turns out fantastic and as another reviewer posted Knorr hollandaise sauce is the BEST, we have been using it for years. I think it is better than homemade. Thank you for sharing!!
My wife liked this but my daughter and I think its just average.
Excellent! No leftovers on this one!
Fabulous recipe ! Quick and easy to put together . Recipe was followed exactly as written. Family loved it !

I can't rate this, because I haven't made it yet.....but I am going to! I have a question to all who HAVE made it: did anyone add asparagus? My typical Eggs Benedict is ONLY proper with asparagus atop the eggs, with the Hollandaise sauce over that.
Followed all the directions - and it was very, very good! We will probably have it again!
Great base recipe that you can switch up depending on what you got in the fridge as far as the meats go. Definitely needs potatoes on the side to help soak up the delicious richness.
Easy to make, tasted wonderful. I did add 2 more eggs, because it seemed a bit dry with 8, but otherwise no changes to the recipe. My 12 year old daughter loved it too.
Delicious

I didn't not see it up the night before so I sliced the English muffins (like you would to toast them) and only used the 1/2s. I also didn't have green onion so I used a handful of chopped onion and garnished with fresh chives. 

We loved this dish! I see a lot of remakes in our future!
Extremely disappointed by this dish. Made my own Hollandaise and all. Tasted like bad bread pudding...and I adore bread pudding.
Tastes so close to the real deal and I can’t believe it’s this easy to make! I’m definitely making this again.

FYI:

Classic (original) Hollandaise Sauce:

3 egg yokes (slightly beat with whisk)
1 stick butter
1/2 tea. lemon juice (or to taste)
dash cayenne pepper

use double boiler to warm butter to melting, NOT HOT.

With whisk, SLOWLY add egg yolks & cayenne pepper, whisking constantly until thickened. (but still pourable)

Take off heat & whisk in lemon juice.

Ready to use.

Not heart-healthy, but ooooooh so good. 

If for some reason your egg yolks curdle (usually do to heat being to hot)), keep on warm & wisk in hot water, 1 teaspoon at a time until smooth. (really, it works)

This is a wonderful recipe. We have it every Christmas morning with a fruit salad. I have used both the green onions as well as sweet onions and it’s good both ways. I use the Knorr hollandaise mix and add some fresh lemon juice and fresh ground pepper when I don’t have time to make my own hollandaise sauce.

I have made this a few times now and everyone has liked it as an easy alternative to eggs Benedict . One important detail is to cut the English muffins into small pieces. Otherwise the egg mixture doesn’t seem to have the proper consistency after baking. I have used Canadian pea meal bacon and also leftover ham on 2 other occasions. Will continue to make this for brunch. Delicious and easy

Made this for the first time Christmas morning and it got rave reviews from my guests. With apologies to the original ‘author’, I made a few changes simply because I always adapt a basic recipe to our taste. First, I cubed the muffins and spread them on a baking sheet to air dry the day before. I used whole milk, real butter (a holiday splurge) omitted the green onion but used onion powder and chives. Also added S&P, Colmans powdered mustard, and a dash of cayenne pepper.
I did use pkg. Hollandaise, but again used real butter, and seasoned with a dash of cayenne and the juice from 1/2 lemon. It was delicious! Served with hash browns and fresh fruit salad, and, of course, Bloody Marys!

While this does not replace traditional Eggs Benedict it’s not bad when you want the basic flavors of EB but don’t want to go thru the effort of making it from scratch, especially when serving a group of people. There is definitely a place for this in my life. It is nice to be able to plop a casserole like this down on the table so you can enjoy eating with your guests instead of standing over the stove preparing each dish individually. By the time you sit down to eat everyone else is done. 
The first time I made it I followed the recipe as written, using Knorr package mix with fresh lemon juice added. MUST have fresh lemon juice in Hollandaise! Also used real butter, not margarine. It really was not bad. The Knorr mix is much better than I anticipated, actually rivaling many made from scratch hollandaise sauces I’ve had. 
The second time I made it I toasted the English muffins first and used thicker slices of a good baked ham cut into cubes which I sautéed in a little bit of butter for more flavor and made my own hollandaise and again, real butter. I also used chopped chives instead of green onions and seasoned the egg mixture with sea salt and fresh cracked black pepper. I made it the morning I served it which helped it not be so soggy, one of the things the Family didn’t like about it the first time I made it. It was even better. Truth be told tho, the difference in the hollandaise sauces was not that great and I would definitely use Knorrs again in a pinch. Overall a goo
left out the onion used minced onion the thing was amazing it only lasted a short time the hollandaise sauce i served on the side sure was a favorite with the family
My family really loved it as is with no tweaks to the recipe. Really easy to just make a 1/2 batch too.

I would make it, as a Canadian, use real Canadian bacon which is Pea-meal bacon, not ham which is what is used in this recipe. Pea-meal is much better tasting, slices it thick and then cube it. Very tasty, too bad it can't be purchased in the U.S. I would also make my own hollandaise sauce, I have a recipe for microwave sauce and it is very good.
My family loved it. It worked great for early breakfast or holidays when your working on dinner cause you make it the previous day!
We had a lot of company for Thanksgiving. The flavor was really good but the presentation not so much. Were I to make it again I'd cut up the Canadian bacon and stir it into the bread.

I was really hoping this would be great . . . but, I was very disappointed. It is more like a bread pudding and I will not make this recipe again.

I don't think there is a good substitute for the real deal when it comes to Eggs Benedict.
Really liked this, reheated well. Good use for english muffins
I served the Hollandaise on the side since not everyone, including me, is not a fan. The casserole was great with or without it.

I got up early, 2am, to make casseroles, for an oven time of 10:30am. I was reluctant to do it much before that. I used flat pepperoni sized Canadian bacon, and a good quality English muffin. I made this for my Dad's surprise 80th Birthday party. I had doubled the recipe, so I was hoping this turned out. I followed the suggestions and made the blender hollandaise sauce. The whole thing was perfect! Not a spec left. The hollandaise sauce was wonderful as well. Many of my relatives want me to send the recipe.
The only change I made was making double the amount of hollandaise sauce. My guests had the option of adding more at the table. Which they did !

I really liked this - in some ways better than my traditional egg casserole. The muffins held up better than white bread. The onions also elevated the flavor. The only pain is having to make the hollandaise, it honestly doesn't need it. I made blender hollandaise.
I made it exactly like the recipe said. My son suggested that it would be better if it had crispy bacon instead of the Canadian bacon. It would add more texture. .

This was a great recipe! We loved it and it also made terrific leftovers-- no lie. 

The only changes I made to this was to add ground mustard and some cayenne to the spices and I doubled the hollandaise sauce. I was happy with the spice additions, and the doubled sauce was okay the night we ate it (breakfast for dinner) but it didn't need two. However, if you are going to eat leftovers (it was lunch for both of us that week) the extra kept it nice and moist and yummy. 

Definitely will make again!
